individual_exchanges.speaker: Chorus_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Two households both alike in dignity In fair Verona where we lay our scene From ancient grudge break to new mutiny Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Doth with their death bury their parents’ strife The fearful passage of their death-marked love And the continuance of their parents’ rage Which but their children’s end naught could remove Is now the two hours’ traffic of our stage The which if you with patient ears attend What here shall miss our toil shall strive to mend

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Gregory on my word we’ll not carry coals

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: No for then we should be colliers

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I mean an we be in choler we’ll draw

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Ay while you live draw your neck out of collar

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I strike quickly being moved

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But thou art not quickly moved to strike

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A dog of the house of Montague moves me

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: To move is to stir and to be valiant is to stand Therefore if thou art moved thou runn’st away

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A dog of that house shall move me to stand I will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague’s

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: That shows thee a weak slave for the weakest goes to the wall

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis true and therefore women being the weaker vessels are ever thrust to the wall Therefore I will push Montague’s men from the wall and thrust his maids to the wall

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis all one I will show myself a tyrant When I have fought with the men I will be civil with the maids I will cut off their heads

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The heads of the maids

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Ay the heads of the maids or their maidenheads Take it in what sense thou wilt

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: They must take it in sense that feel it

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Sampson_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.Gregory_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis well thou art not fish if thou hadst thou hadst been poor-john Draw thy tool Here comes of the house of Montagues

individual_exchanges.speaker: PrinceEscalus_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Rebellious subjects enemies to peace Profaners of this neighbor-stainèd steel Will they not hear What ho You men you beasts That quench the fire of your pernicious rage With purple fountains issuing from your veins On pain of torture from those bloody hands Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground And hear the sentence of your movèd prince Three civil brawls bred of an airy word By thee old Capulet and Montague Have thrice disturbed the quiet of our streets And made Verona’s ancient citizens Cast by their grave-beseeming ornaments To wield old partisans in hands as old Cankered with peace to part your cankered hate If ever you disturb our streets again Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace For this time all the rest depart away You Capulet shall go along with me And Montague come you this afternoon To know our farther pleasure in this case To old Free-town our common judgment-place Once more on pain of death all men depart

individual_exchanges.speaker: Montague_Rom

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Here were the servants of your adversary And yours close fighting ere I did approach I drew to part them In the instant came The fiery Tybalt with his sword prepared Which as he breathed defiance to my ears He swung about his head and cut the winds Who nothing hurt withal hissed him in scorn While we were interchanging thrusts and blows Came more and more and fought on part and part Till the Prince came who parted either part

individual_exchanges.speaker: LadyMontague_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O where is Romeo Saw you him today Right glad I am he was not at this fray

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Madam an hour before the worshiped sun Peered forth the golden window of the east A troubled mind drove me to walk abroad Where underneath the grove of sycamore That westward rooteth from this city side So early walking did I see your son Towards him I made but he was ’ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood I measuring his affections by my own Which then most sought where most might not be found Being one too many by my weary self Pursued my humor not pursuing his And gladly shunned who gladly fled from me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Madam an hour before the worshiped sun Peered forth the golden window of the east A troubled mind drove me to walk abroad Where underneath the grove of sycamore That westward rooteth from this city side So early walking did I see your son Towards him I made but he was ’ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood I measuring his affections by my own Which then most sought where most might not be found Being one too many by my weary self Pursued my humor not pursuing his And gladly shunned who gladly fled from me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Montague_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Many a morning hath he there been seen With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs But all so soon as the all-cheering sun Should in the farthest east begin to draw The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed Away from light steals home my heavy son And private in his chamber pens himself Shuts up his windows locks fair daylight out And makes himself an artificial night Black and portentous must this humor prove Unless good counsel may the cause remove

individual_exchanges.text: I neither know it nor can learn of him

individual_exchanges.text: Have you importuned him by any means

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Have you importuned him by any means

individual_exchanges.speaker: Montague_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Both by myself and many other friends But he his own affections’ counselor Is to himself I will not say how true But to himself so secret and so close So far from sounding and discovery As is the bud bit with an envious worm Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air Or dedicate his beauty to the same Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow We would as willingly give cure as know

individual_exchanges.text: Is the day so young

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But new struck nine

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Ay me sad hours seem long Was that my father that went hence so fast

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: It was What sadness lengthens Romeo’s hours

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Not having that which having makes them short

individual_exchanges.text: In love

individual_exchanges.text: Out

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Of love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Out of her favor where I am in love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Alas that love so gentle in his view Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Alas that love whose view is muffled still Should without eyes see pathways to his will Where shall we dine O me What fray was here Yet tell me not for I have heard it all Here’s much to do with hate but more with love Why then O brawling love O loving hate O anything of nothing first create O heavy lightness serious vanity Misshapen chaos of well-seeming forms Feather of lead bright smoke cold fire sick health Still-waking sleep that is not what it is This love feel I that feel no love in this Dost thou not laugh

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: No coz I rather weep

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Good heart at what

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: At thy good heart’s oppression

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Why such is love’s transgression Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast Which thou wilt propagate to have it pressed With more of thine This love that thou hast shown Doth add more grief to too much of mine own Love is a smoke made with the fume of sighs Being purged a fire sparkling in lovers’ eyes Being vexed a sea nourished with loving tears What is it else A madness most discreet A choking gall and a preserving sweet Farewell my coz

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Soft I will go along An if you leave me so you do me wrong

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Tut I have lost myself I am not here This is not Romeo He’s some other where

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Tell me in sadness who is that you love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What shall I groan and tell thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Groan Why no But sadly tell me who

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A sick man in sadness makes his will A word ill urged to one that is so ill In sadness cousin I do love a woman

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I aimed so near when I supposed you loved

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A right good markman And she’s fair I love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A right fair mark fair coz is soonest hit

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Well in that hit you miss She’ll not be hit With Cupid’s arrow She hath Dian’s wit And in strong proof of chastity well armed From love’s weak childish bow she lives uncharmed She will not stay the siege of loving terms Nor bide th’ encounter of assailing eyes Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold O she is rich in beauty only poor That when she dies with beauty dies her store

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: She hath and in that sparing makes huge waste For beauty starved with her severity Cuts beauty off from all posterity She is too fair too wise wisely too fair To merit bliss by making me despair She hath forsworn to love and in that vow Do I live dead that live to tell it now

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Be ruled by me Forget to think of her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O teach me how I should forget to think

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: By giving liberty unto thine eyes Examine other beauties

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis the way To call hers exquisite in question more These happy masks that kiss fair ladies’ brows Being black puts us in mind they hide the fair He that is strucken blind cannot forget The precious treasure of his eyesight lost Show me a mistress that is passing fair What doth her beauty serve but as a note Where I may read who passed that passing fair Farewell Thou canst not teach me to forget

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I’ll pay that doctrine or else die in debt

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But Montague is bound as well as I In penalty alike and ’tis not hard I think For men so old as we to keep the peace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But Montague is bound as well as I In penalty alike and ’tis not hard I think For men so old as we to keep the peace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Paris_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Of honorable reckoning are you both And pity ’tis you lived at odds so long But now my lord what say you to my suit

individual_exchanges.speaker: Paris_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Of honorable reckoning are you both And pity ’tis you lived at odds so long But now my lord what say you to my suit

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But saying o’er what I have said before My child is yet a stranger in the world She hath not seen the change of fourteen years Let two more summers wither in their pride Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But saying o’er what I have said before My child is yet a stranger in the world She hath not seen the change of fourteen years Let two more summers wither in their pride Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride

individual_exchanges.speaker: Paris_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Younger than she are happy mothers made

individual_exchanges.speaker: Paris_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Younger than she are happy mothers made

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: And too soon marred are those so early made Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she She’s the hopeful lady of my earth But woo her gentle Paris get her heart My will to her consent is but a part And she agreed within her scope of choice Lies my consent and fair according voice This night I hold an old accustomed feast Whereto I have invited many a guest Such as I love and you among the store One more most welcome makes my number more At my poor house look to behold this night Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-appareled April on the heel Of limping winter treads even such delight Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night Inherit at my house Hear all all see And like her most whose merit most shall be Which on more view of many mine being one May stand in number though in reck’ning none Come go with me To Servingman giving him a list Go sirrah trudge about Through fair Verona find those persons out Whose names are written there and to them say My house and welcome on their pleasure stay

individual_exchanges.speaker: SERVANTS.CAPULET.X.1_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Find them out whose names are written here It is written that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last the fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets But I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ I must to the learned In good time

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Tut man one fire burns out another’s burning One pain is lessened by another’s anguish Turn giddy and be helped by backward turning One desperate grief cures with another’s languish Take thou some new infection to thy eye And the rank poison of the old will die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves With all the admirèd beauties of Verona Go thither and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show And I will make thee think thy swan a crow

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: When the devout religion of mine eye Maintains such falsehood then turn tears to fire And these who often drowned could never die Transparent heretics be burnt for liars One fairer than my love The all-seeing sun Ne’er saw her match since first the world begun

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Tut you saw her fair none else being by Herself poised with herself in either eye But in that crystal scales let there be weighed Your lady’s love against some other maid That I will show you shining at this feast And she shall scant show well that now seems best

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I’ll go along no such sight to be shown But to rejoice in splendor of mine own

individual_exchanges.speaker: LadyCapulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nurse where’s my daughter Call her forth to me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Now by my maidenhead at twelve year old I bade her come What lamb What ladybird God forbid Where’s this girl What Juliet

individual_exchanges.text: A fortnight and odd days

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Even or odd of all days in the year Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen Susan and she God rest all Christian souls Were of an age Well Susan is with God She was too good for me But as I said On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen That shall she Marry I remember it well ’Tis since the earthquake now eleven years And she was weaned I never shall forget it Of all the days of the year upon that day For I had then laid wormwood to my dug Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall My lord and you were then at Mantua Nay I do bear a brain But as I said When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter pretty fool To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug Shake quoth the dovehouse ’Twas no need I trow To bid me trudge And since that time it is eleven years For then she could stand high-lone Nay by th’ rood She could have run and waddled all about For even the day before she broke her brow And then my husband God be with his soul He was a merry man took up the child Yea quoth he Dost thou fall upon thy face Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit Wilt thou not Jule And by my holidam The pretty wretch left crying and said Ay To see now how a jest shall come about I warrant an I should live a thousand years I never should forget it Wilt thou not Jule quoth he And pretty fool it stinted and said Ay

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Yes madam yet I cannot choose but laugh To think it should leave crying and say Ay And yet I warrant it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cock’rel’s stone A perilous knock and it cried bitterly Yea quoth my husband Fall’st upon thy face Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age Wilt thou not Jule It stinted and said Ay

individual_exchanges.speaker: LadyCapulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What say you Can you love the gentleman This night you shall behold him at our feast Read o’er the volume of young Paris’ face And find delight writ there with beauty’s pen Examine every married lineament And see how one another lends content And what obscured in this fair volume lies Find written in the margent of his eyes This precious book of love this unbound lover To beautify him only lacks a cover The fish lives in the sea and ’tis much pride For fair without the fair within to hide That book in many’s eyes doth share the glory That in gold clasps locks in the golden story So shall you share all that he doth possess By having him making yourself no less

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The date is out of such prolixity We’ll have no Cupid hoodwinked with a scarf Bearing a Tartar’s painted bow of lath Scaring the ladies like a crowkeeper Nor no without-book prologue faintly spoke After the prompter for our entrance But let them measure us by what they will We’ll measure them a measure and be gone

individual_exchanges.text: In bed asleep while they do dream things true

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O then I see Queen Mab hath been with you She is the fairies’ midwife and she comes In shape no bigger than an agate stone On the forefinger of an alderman Drawn with a team of little atomi Over men’s noses as they lie asleep Her wagon spokes made of long spinners’ legs The cover of the wings of grasshoppers Her traces of the smallest spider web Her collars of the moonshine’s wat’ry beams Her whip of cricket’s bone the lash of film Her wagoner a small gray-coated gnat Not half so big as a round little worm Pricked from the lazy finger of a maid Her chariot is an empty hazelnut Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub Time out o’ mind the fairies’ coachmakers And in this state she gallops night by night Through lovers’ brains and then they dream of love On courtiers’ knees that dream on cur’sies straight O’er lawyers’ fingers who straight dream on fees O’er ladies’ lips who straight on kisses dream Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are Sometime she gallops o’er a courtier’s nose And then dreams he of smelling out a suit And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep Then he dreams of another benefice Sometime she driveth o’er a soldier’s neck And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats Of breaches ambuscadoes Spanish blades Of healths five fathom deep and then anon Drums in his ear at which he starts and wakes And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two And sleeps again This is that very Mab That plats the manes of horses in the night And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs Which once untangled much misfortune bodes This is the hag when maids lie on their backs That presses them and learns them first to bear Making them women of good carriage This is she

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: True I talk of dreams Which are the children of an idle brain Begot of nothing but vain fantasy Which is as thin of substance as the air And more inconstant than the wind who woos Even now the frozen bosom of the north And being angered puffs away from thence Turning his side to the dew-dropping south

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I fear too early for my mind misgives Some consequence yet hanging in the stars Shall bitterly begin his fearful date With this night’s revels and expire the term Of a despisèd life closed in my breast By some vile forfeit of untimely death But he that hath the steerage of my course Direct my sail On lusty gentlemen

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Welcome gentlemen Ladies that have their toes Unplagued with corns will walk a bout with you Ah my mistresses which of you all Will now deny to dance She that makes dainty She I’ll swear hath corns Am I come near you now Welcome gentlemen I have seen the day That I have worn a visor and could tell A whispering tale in a fair lady’s ear Such as would please ’Tis gone ’tis gone ’tis gone You are welcome gentlemen Come musicians play Music plays and they dance A hall a hall give room And foot it girls More light you knaves and turn the tables up And quench the fire the room is grown too hot Ah sirrah this unlooked-for sport comes well Nay sit nay sit good cousin Capulet For you and I are past our dancing days How long is ’t now since last yourself and I Were in a mask

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O she doth teach the torches to burn bright It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night As a rich jewel in an Ethiop’s ear Beauty too rich for use for Earth too dear So shows a snowy dove trooping with crows As yonder lady o’er her fellows shows The measure done I’ll watch her place of stand And touching hers make blessèd my rude hand Did my heart love till now Forswear it sight For I ne’er saw true beauty till this night

individual_exchanges.text: This by his voice should be a Montague Fetch me my rapier boy Page exits What dares the slave Come hither covered with an antic face To fleer and scorn at our solemnity Now by the stock and honor of my kin To strike him dead I hold it not a sin

individual_exchanges.speaker: Capulet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Content thee gentle coz Let him alone He bears him like a portly gentleman And to say truth Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-governed youth I would not for the wealth of all this town Here in my house do him disparagement Therefore be patient Take no note of him It is my will the which if thou respect Show a fair presence and put off these frowns An ill-beseeming semblance for a feast

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Come hither nurse What is yond gentleman

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The son and heir of old Tiberio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What’s he that now is going out of door

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Marry that I think be young Petruchio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What’s he that follows here that would not dance

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I know not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Go ask his name The Nurse goes If he be marrièd My grave is like to be my wedding bed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: His name is Romeo and a Montague The only son of your great enemy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: My only love sprung from my only hate Too early seen unknown and known too late Prodigious birth of love it is to me That I must love a loathèd enemy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What’s this What’s this

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A rhyme I learned even now Of one I danced withal

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Anon anon Come let’s away The strangers all are gone

individual_exchanges.speaker: Chorus_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Now old desire doth in his deathbed lie And young affection gapes to be his heir That fair for which love groaned for and would die With tender Juliet matched is now not fair Now Romeo is beloved and loves again Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks But to his foe supposed he must complain And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks Being held a foe he may not have access To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear And she as much in love her means much less To meet her new belovèd anywhere But passion lends them power time means to meet Temp’ring extremities with extreme sweet

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Can I go forward when my heart is here Turn back dull earth and find thy center out

individual_exchanges.text: He is wise And on my life hath stol’n him home to bed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall Call good Mercutio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall Call good Mercutio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay I’ll conjure too Romeo Humors Madman Passion Lover Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh Speak but one rhyme and I am satisfied Cry but Ay me pronounce but love and dove Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word One nickname for her purblind son and heir Young Abraham Cupid he that shot so trim When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid He heareth not he stirreth not he moveth not The ape is dead and I must conjure him I conjure thee by Rosaline’s bright eyes By her high forehead and her scarlet lip By her fine foot straight leg and quivering thigh And the demesnes that there adjacent lie That in thy likeness thou appear to us

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay I’ll conjure too Romeo Humors Madman Passion Lover Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh Speak but one rhyme and I am satisfied Cry but Ay me pronounce but love and dove Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word One nickname for her purblind son and heir Young Abraham Cupid he that shot so trim When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid He heareth not he stirreth not he moveth not The ape is dead and I must conjure him I conjure thee by Rosaline’s bright eyes By her high forehead and her scarlet lip By her fine foot straight leg and quivering thigh And the demesnes that there adjacent lie That in thy likeness thou appear to us

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: An if he hear thee thou wilt anger him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: An if he hear thee thou wilt anger him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: This cannot anger him ’Twould anger him To raise a spirit in his mistress’ circle Of some strange nature letting it there stand Till she had laid it and conjured it down That were some spite My invocation Is fair and honest In his mistress’ name I conjure only but to raise up him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: This cannot anger him ’Twould anger him To raise a spirit in his mistress’ circle Of some strange nature letting it there stand Till she had laid it and conjured it down That were some spite My invocation Is fair and honest In his mistress’ name I conjure only but to raise up him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Come he hath hid himself among these trees To be consorted with the humorous night Blind is his love and best befits the dark

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Come he hath hid himself among these trees To be consorted with the humorous night Blind is his love and best befits the dark

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: If love be blind love cannot hit the mark Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone O Romeo that she were O that she were An open-arse thou a pop’rin pear Romeo good night I’ll to my truckle bed This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep Come shall we go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: If love be blind love cannot hit the mark Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone O Romeo that she were O that she were An open-arse thou a pop’rin pear Romeo good night I’ll to my truckle bed This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep Come shall we go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Go then for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Go then for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: He jests at scars that never felt a wound Enter Juliet above But soft what light through yonder window breaks It is the East and Juliet is the sun Arise fair sun and kill the envious moon Who is already sick and pale with grief That thou her maid art far more fair than she Be not her maid since she is envious Her vestal livery is but sick and green And none but fools do wear it Cast it off It is my lady O it is my love O that she knew she were She speaks yet she says nothing What of that Her eye discourses I will answer it I am too bold ’Tis not to me she speaks Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven Having some business do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return What if her eyes were there they in her head The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars As daylight doth a lamp her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night See how she leans her cheek upon her hand O that I were a glove upon that hand That I might touch that cheek

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Ay me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: She speaks O speak again bright angel for thou art As glorious to this night being o’er my head As is a wingèd messenger of heaven Unto the white-upturnèd wond’ring eyes Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him When he bestrides the lazy puffing clouds And sails upon the bosom of the air

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O Romeo Romeo wherefore art thou Romeo Deny thy father and refuse thy name Or if thou wilt not be but sworn my love And I’ll no longer be a Capulet

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Shall I hear more or shall I speak at this

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis but thy name that is my enemy Thou art thyself though not a Montague What’s Montague It is nor hand nor foot Nor arm nor face O be some other name Belonging to a man What’s in a name That which we call a rose By any other word would smell as sweet So Romeo would were he not Romeo called Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title Romeo doff thy name And for thy name which is no part of thee Take all myself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I take thee at thy word Call me but love and I’ll be new baptized Henceforth I never will be Romeo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What man art thou that thus bescreened in night So stumblest on my counsel

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am My name dear saint is hateful to myself Because it is an enemy to thee Had I it written I would tear the word

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: My ears have yet not drunk a hundred words Of thy tongue’s uttering yet I know the sound Art thou not Romeo and a Montague

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Neither fair maid if either thee dislike

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: How camest thou hither tell me and wherefore The orchard walls are high and hard to climb And the place death considering who thou art If any of my kinsmen find thee here

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: With love’s light wings did I o’erperch these walls For stony limits cannot hold love out And what love can do that dares love attempt Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: If they do see thee they will murder thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Alack there lies more peril in thine eye Than twenty of their swords Look thou but sweet And I am proof against their enmity

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I would not for the world they saw thee here

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I have night’s cloak to hide me from their eyes And but thou love me let them find me here My life were better ended by their hate Than death proroguèd wanting of thy love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: By whose direction found’st thou out this place

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: By love that first did prompt me to inquire He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes I am no pilot yet wert thou as far As that vast shore washed with the farthest sea I should adventure for such merchandise

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight Fain would I dwell on form fain fain deny What I have spoke But farewell compliment Dost thou love me I know thou wilt say Ay And I will take thy word Yet if thou swear’st Thou mayst prove false At lovers’ perjuries They say Jove laughs O gentle Romeo If thou dost love pronounce it faithfully Or if thou thinkest I am too quickly won I’ll frown and be perverse and say thee nay So thou wilt woo but else not for the world In truth fair Montague I am too fond And therefore thou mayst think my havior light But trust me gentleman I’ll prove more true Than those that have more coying to be strange I should have been more strange I must confess But that thou overheard’st ere I was ware My true-love passion Therefore pardon me And not impute this yielding to light love Which the dark night hath so discoverèd

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Lady by yonder blessèd moon I vow That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O swear not by the moon th’ inconstant moon That monthly changes in her circled orb Lest that thy love prove likewise variable

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What shall I swear by

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Do not swear at all Or if thou wilt swear by thy gracious self Which is the god of my idolatry And I’ll believe thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: If my heart’s dear love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Well do not swear Although I joy in thee I have no joy of this contract tonight It is too rash too unadvised too sudden Too like the lightning which doth cease to be Ere one can say It lightens Sweet good night This bud of love by summer’s ripening breath May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet Good night good night As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Th’ exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it And yet I would it were to give again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Wouldst thou withdraw it For what purpose love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: But to be frank and give it thee again And yet I wish but for the thing I have My bounty is as boundless as the sea My love as deep The more I give to thee The more I have for both are infinite Nurse calls from within I hear some noise within Dear love adieu Anon good nurse Sweet Montague be true Stay but a little I will come again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O blessèd blessèd night I am afeard Being in night all this is but a dream Too flattering sweet to be substantial

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Three words dear Romeo and good night indeed If that thy bent of love be honorable Thy purpose marriage send me word tomorrow By one that I’ll procure to come to thee Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite And all my fortunes at thy foot I’ll lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Madam

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Madam

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I come anon But if thou meanest not well I do beseech thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Madam

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Madam

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: By and by I come To cease thy strife and leave me to my grief Tomorrow will I send

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: So thrive my soul

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A thousand times good night

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A thousand times the worse to want thy light Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books But love from love toward school with heavy looks

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Hist Romeo hist O for a falc’ner’s voice To lure this tassel-gentle back again Bondage is hoarse and may not speak aloud Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine With repetition of My Romeo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: It is my soul that calls upon my name How silver-sweet sound lovers’ tongues by night Like softest music to attending ears

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Romeo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: My dear

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: What o’clock tomorrow Shall I send to thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: By the hour of nine

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I will not fail ’Tis twenty year till then I have forgot why I did call thee back

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Let me stand here till thou remember it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I shall forget to have thee still stand there Rememb’ring how I love thy company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: And I’ll still stay to have thee still forget Forgetting any other home but this

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis almost morning I would have thee gone And yet no farther than a wanton’s bird That lets it hop a little from his hand Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves And with a silken thread plucks it back again So loving-jealous of his liberty

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I would I were thy bird

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Sweet so would I Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing Good night good night Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say Good night till it be morrow

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes peace in thy breast Would I were sleep and peace so sweet to rest Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell His help to crave and my dear hap to tell

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night Check’ring the eastern clouds with streaks of light And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels Now ere the sun advance his burning eye The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers The Earth that’s nature’s mother is her tomb What is her burying grave that is her womb And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find Many for many virtues excellent None but for some and yet all different O mickle is the powerful grace that lies In plants herbs stones and their true qualities For naught so vile that on the Earth doth live But to the Earth some special good doth give Nor aught so good but strained from that fair use Revolts from true birth stumbling on abuse Virtue itself turns vice being misapplied And vice sometime by action dignified Enter Romeo Within the infant rind of this weak flower Poison hath residence and medicine power For this being smelt with that part cheers each part Being tasted stays all senses with the heart Two such opposèd kings encamp them still In man as well as herbs grace and rude will And where the worser is predominant Full soon the canker death eats up that plant

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Good morrow father

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Benedicite What early tongue so sweet saluteth me Young son it argues a distempered head So soon to bid Good morrow to thy bed Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye And where care lodges sleep will never lie But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain Doth couch his limbs there golden sleep doth reign Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused with some distemp’rature Or if not so then here I hit it right Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: That last is true The sweeter rest was mine

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: God pardon sin Wast thou with Rosaline

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: With Rosaline my ghostly father No I have forgot that name and that name’s woe

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: That’s my good son But where hast thou been then

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again I have been feasting with mine enemy Where on a sudden one hath wounded me That’s by me wounded Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies I bear no hatred blessèd man for lo My intercession likewise steads my foe

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Be plain good son and homely in thy drift Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet As mine on hers so hers is set on mine And all combined save what thou must combine By holy marriage When and where and how We met we wooed and made exchange of vow I’ll tell thee as we pass but this I pray That thou consent to marry us today

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Holy Saint Francis what a change is here Is Rosaline that thou didst love so dear So soon forsaken Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts but in their eyes Jesu Maria what a deal of brine Hath washed thy sallow cheeks for Rosaline How much salt water thrown away in waste To season love that of it doth not taste The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears Thy old groans yet ringing in mine ancient ears Lo here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet If e’er thou wast thyself and these woes thine Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline And art thou changed Pronounce this sentence then Women may fall when there’s no strength in men

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: For doting not for loving pupil mine

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: And bad’st me bury love

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Not in a grave To lay one in another out to have

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I pray thee chide me not Her I love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow The other did not so

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O she knew well Thy love did read by rote that could not spell But come young waverer come go with me In one respect I’ll thy assistant be For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households’ rancor to pure love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O let us hence I stand on sudden haste

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Wisely and slow They stumble that run fast

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Where the devil should this Romeo be Came he not home tonight

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Not to his father’s I spoke with his man

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Why that same pale hard-hearted wench that Rosaline Torments him so that he will sure run mad

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Tybalt the kinsman to old Capulet Hath sent a letter to his father’s house

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A challenge on my life

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Romeo will answer it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Any man that can write may answer a letter

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay he will answer the letter’s master how he dares being dared

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Alas poor Romeo he is already dead stabbed with a white wench’s black eye run through the ear with a love-song the very pin of his heart cleft with the blind bow-boy’s butt shaft And is he a man to encounter Tybalt

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Why what is Tybalt

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: More than prince of cats O he’s the courageous captain of compliments He fights as you sing prick-song keeps time distance and proportion He rests his minim rests one two and the third in your bosom the very butcher of a silk button a duelist a duelist a gentleman of the very first house of the first and second cause Ah the immortal passado the punto reverso the hay

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The what

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The pox of such antic lisping affecting phantasimes these new tuners of accent By Jesu a very good blade A very tall man A very good whore Why is not this a lamentable thing grandsire that we should be thus afflicted with these strange flies these fashion-mongers these pardon-me ’s who stand so much on the new form that they cannot sit at ease on the old bench O their bones their bones

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Here comes Romeo here comes Romeo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Here comes Romeo here comes Romeo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Without his roe like a dried herring O flesh flesh how art thou fishified Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in Laura to his lady was a kitchen wench marry she had a better love to berhyme her Dido a dowdy Cleopatra a gypsy Helen and Hero hildings and harlots Thisbe a gray eye or so but not to the purpose Signior Romeo bonjour There’s a French salutation to your French slop You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Without his roe like a dried herring O flesh flesh how art thou fishified Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in Laura to his lady was a kitchen wench marry she had a better love to berhyme her Dido a dowdy Cleopatra a gypsy Helen and Hero hildings and harlots Thisbe a gray eye or so but not to the purpose Signior Romeo bonjour There’s a French salutation to your French slop You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Good morrow to you both What counterfeit did I give you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Good morrow to you both What counterfeit did I give you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The slip sir the slip Can you not conceive

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The slip sir the slip Can you not conceive

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Pardon good Mercutio my business was great and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Pardon good Mercutio my business was great and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: That’s as much as to say such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: That’s as much as to say such a case as yours constrains a man to bow in the hams

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Meaning to curtsy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Meaning to curtsy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thou hast most kindly hit it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thou hast most kindly hit it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A most courteous exposition

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: A most courteous exposition

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay I am the very pink of courtesy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay I am the very pink of courtesy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Pink for flower

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Pink for flower

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Right

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Right

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Why then is my pump well flowered

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Why then is my pump well flowered

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Sure wit follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump that when the single sole of it is worn the jest may remain after the wearing solely singular

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Sure wit follow me this jest now till thou hast worn out thy pump that when the single sole of it is worn the jest may remain after the wearing solely singular

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O single-soled jest solely singular for the singleness

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O single-soled jest solely singular for the singleness

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Come between us good Benvolio My wits faints

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Come between us good Benvolio My wits faints

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Switch and spurs switch and spurs or I’ll cry a match

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Switch and spurs switch and spurs or I’ll cry a match

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay if our wits run the wild-goose chase I am done for thou hast more of the wild goose in one of thy wits than I am sure I have in my whole five Was I with you there for the goose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay if our wits run the wild-goose chase I am done for thou hast more of the wild goose in one of thy wits than I am sure I have in my whole five Was I with you there for the goose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay good goose bite not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay good goose bite not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting it is a most sharp sauce

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting it is a most sharp sauce

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: And is it not then well served into a sweet goose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: And is it not then well served into a sweet goose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Now afore God I am so vexed that every part about me quivers Scurvy knave To Romeo Pray you sir a word And as I told you my young lady bid me inquire you out What she bid me say I will keep to myself But first let me tell you if you should lead her in a fool’s paradise as they say it were a very gross kind of behavior as they say For the gentlewoman is young and therefore if you should deal double with her truly it were an ill thing to be offered to any gentlewoman and very weak dealing

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse In half an hour she promised to return Perchance she cannot meet him That’s not so O she is lame Love’s heralds should be thoughts Which ten times faster glides than the sun’s beams Driving back shadows over louring hills Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw Love And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day’s journey and from nine till twelve Is three long hours yet she is not come Had she affections and warm youthful blood She would be as swift in motion as a ball My words would bandy her to my sweet love And his to me But old folks many feign as they were dead Unwieldy slow heavy and pale as lead Enter Nurse and Peter O God she comes O honey nurse what news Hast thou met with him Send thy man away

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Peter stay at the gate

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Peter stay at the gate

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Now good sweet nurse O Lord why lookest thou sad Though news be sad yet tell them merrily If good thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I am aweary Give me leave awhile Fie how my bones ache What a jaunt have I

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news Nay come I pray thee speak Good good nurse speak

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Jesu what haste Can you not stay awhile Do you not see that I am out of breath

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse Is thy news good or bad Answer to that Say either and I’ll stay the circumstance Let me be satisfied is ’t good or bad

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Well you have made a simple choice You know not how to choose a man Romeo No not he Though his face be better than any man’s yet his leg excels all men’s and for a hand and a foot and a body though they be not to be talked on yet they are past compare He is not the flower of courtesy but I’ll warrant him as gentle as a lamb Go thy ways wench Serve God What have you dined at home

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: No no But all this did I know before What says he of our marriage What of that

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Lord how my head aches What a head have I It beats as it would fall in twenty pieces My back o’ t’ other side Ah my back my back Beshrew your heart for sending me about To catch my death with jaunting up and down

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I’ faith I am sorry that thou art not well Sweet sweet sweet nurse tell me what says my love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Your love says like an honest gentleman and a courteous and a kind and a handsome and I warrant a virtuous Where is your mother

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Where is my mother Why she is within Where should she be How oddly thou repliest Your love says like an honest gentleman Where is your mother

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O God’s lady dear Are you so hot Marry come up I trow Is this the poultice for my aching bones Henceforward do your messages yourself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Here’s such a coil Come what says Romeo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Have you got leave to go to shrift today

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: I have

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nurse_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’ cell There stays a husband to make you a wife Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news Hie you to church I must another way To fetch a ladder by the which your love Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark I am the drudge and toil in your delight But you shall bear the burden soon at night Go I’ll to dinner Hie you to the cell

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Hie to high fortune Honest nurse farewell

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: So smile the heavens upon this holy act That after-hours with sorrow chide us not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Amen amen But come what sorrow can It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight Do thou but close our hands with holy words Then love-devouring death do what he dare It is enough I may but call her mine

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarLawrence_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: These violent delights have violent ends And in their triumph die like fire and powder Which as they kiss consume The sweetest honey Is loathsome in his own deliciousness And in the taste confounds the appetite Therefore love moderately Long love doth so Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow Enter Juliet Here comes the lady O so light a foot Will ne’er wear out the everlasting flint A lover may bestride the gossamers That idles in the wanton summer air And yet not fall so light is vanity

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Good even to my ghostly confessor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Juliet_Rom

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mercutio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Nay an there were two such we should have none shortly for one would kill the other Thou why thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter With another for tying his new shoes with old ribbon And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling

individual_exchanges.text: No ’tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church door but ’tis enough ’Twill serve Ask for me tomorrow and you shall find me a grave man I am peppered I warrant for this world A plague o’ both your houses Zounds a dog a rat a mouse a cat to scratch a man to death A braggart a rogue a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic Why the devil came you between us I was hurt under your arm

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: This gentleman the Prince’s near ally My very friend hath got this mortal hurt In my behalf My reputation stained With Tybalt’s slander Tybalt that an hour Hath been my cousin O sweet Juliet Thy beauty hath made me effeminate And in my temper softened valor’s steel

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: O Romeo Romeo brave Mercutio is dead That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds Which too untimely here did scorn the earth

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: This day’s black fate on more days doth depend This but begins the woe others must end

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Romeo_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Alive in triumph and Mercutio slain Away to heaven respective lenity And fire-eyed fury be my conduct now Now Tybalt take the villain back again That late thou gavest me for Mercutio’s soul Is but a little way above our heads Staying for thine to keep him company Either thou or I or both must go with him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Benvolio_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: Tybalt here slain whom Romeo’s hand did slay Romeo that spoke him fair bid him bethink How nice the quarrel was and urged withal Your high displeasure All this utterèd With gentle breath calm look knees humbly bowed Could not take truce with the unruly spleen Of Tybalt deaf to peace but that he tilts With piercing steel at bold Mercutio’s breast Who all as hot turns deadly point to point And with a martial scorn with one hand beats Cold death aside and with the other sends It back to Tybalt whose dexterity Retorts it Romeo he cries aloud Hold friends Friends part and swifter than his tongue His agile arm beats down their fatal points And ’twixt them rushes underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio and then Tybalt fled But by and by comes back to Romeo Who had but newly entertained revenge And to ’t they go like lightning for ere I Could draw to part them was stout Tybalt slain And as he fell did Romeo turn and fly This is the truth or let Benvolio die

individual_exchanges.speaker: PrinceEscalus_Rom
individual_exchanges.text: And for that offense Immediately we do exile him hence I have an interest in your hearts’ proceeding My blood for your rude brawls doth lie a-bleeding But I’ll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine I will be deaf to pleading and excuses Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses Therefore use none Let Romeo hence in haste Else when he is found that hour is his last Bear hence this body and attend our will Mercy but murders pardoning those that kill
